title_translation.en: Learn Vocabulary Through Stories - Why was the question of state language so important?
title_translation.es: Aprende vocabulario a trav√©s de historias - ¬øPor qu√© era tan importante la cuesti√≥n del idioma estatal?

content_translation.en:
As soon as the discussion began about making Urdu the sole state language, students, educated middle-class society, intellectuals, and politicians in East Bengal realized that this would bring extreme disaster for Bengalis. They understood that this would establish the dominance of Urdu-speaking people in Pakistan, and Bengalis would fall behind compared to Urdu-knowing communities in terms of opportunities for jobs in government and military services. The dream of development and social progress of Bengali Muslims that had been created as a result of the establishment of Pakistan would be severely damaged.

Yet the reality of Pakistan was that in the eastern part of the country - and even considering the entire country - the language of the majority people was Bengali. In West Pakistan, just over 40 percent of people spoke Punjabi, and only four percent spoke Urdu.

Even though Bengali was the language of the majority people, the fact that Bengali would not become one of the state languages of Pakistan had created tremendous resentment among the students and educated communities of East Bengal.

"On one hand, there are emotions of language and identity - besides that, there is an economic aspect," said Raunaq Jahan, professor and analyst at Columbia University.

According to him, "At that time, employment meant government jobs. But if Urdu became the state language, Bengalis would have to learn Urdu to get government jobs or jobs in the military, they would have to compete with Urdu speakers - as a result, they would be at a disadvantage. So for students, this was a question of the future."
content_translation.es:
Tan pronto como comenz√≥ la discusi√≥n sobre hacer del **Urdu** el √∫nico idioma **state**, los estudiantes, la sociedad **middle-class** educada, los **intellectuals** y los pol√≠ticos en **East Bengal** se dieron cuenta de que esto traer√≠a un desastre extremo para los bengal√≠es. Entendieron que esto establecer√≠a la **dominance** de las personas de habla **Urdu** en **Pakistan**, los bengal√≠es se quedar√≠an atr√°s en comparaci√≥n con las comunidades que conocen **Urdu** en t√©rminos de **opportunities** de trabajo en el gobierno y los servicios militares. El sue√±o de **development** y **social progress** de los musulmanes bengal√≠es que se hab√≠a creado como resultado del establecimiento de **Pakistan** se da√±ar√≠a severamente.

Sin embargo, la **reality** de **Pakistan** era que en la parte oriental del pa√≠s - e incluso considerando todo el pa√≠s - el idioma de la **majority** de las personas era bengal√≠. En **West Pakistan**, poco m√°s del 40 por ciento de las personas hablaban **Punjabi**, y solo el cuatro por ciento hablaba **Urdu**.

Aunque el bengal√≠ era el idioma de la **majority** de las personas, el hecho de que el bengal√≠ no se convertir√≠a en uno de los idiomas estatales de **Pakistan** hab√≠a creado un tremendo **resentment** entre los estudiantes y las comunidades educadas de **East Bengal**.

"Por un lado, est√°n las **emotions** del idioma y la identidad - adem√°s de eso, hay un aspecto **economic**," dijo **Raunaq Jahan**, profesor y analista de la **Columbia University**.

Seg√∫n √©l, "En ese momento, **employment** significaba trabajos gubernamentales. Pero si **Urdu** se convert√≠a en el idioma estatal, los bengal√≠es tendr√≠an que aprender **Urdu** para conseguir trabajos gubernamentales o trabajos en el ej√©rcito, tendr√≠an que competir con hablantes de **Urdu** - como resultado, estar√≠an en **disadvantage**. As√≠ que para los estudiantes, esta era una cuesti√≥n del futuro."
